oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Poets And Prophets program - Hank Cochran - 2007-03-24
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Interview program with songwriter Hank Cochran from the Ford Theater at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum on March 24, 2007.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Hank Cochran;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Recording begins during opening comments by Michael Gray. Includes selected recorded audio excerpts and audio from video. Subjects include: (00:00) introductory comments / (02:28) Video screening from the Porter Wagoner show / (05:15) Introduction of Hank Cochran / (07:11) Hank's upbringing and musical influences / (08:41) Writing poems as a child in school / (10:49) Talks about photograph with first guitar / (11:57) Listening to the Grand Ole Opry in the family car at night and getting a whipping for it / (13:43) Plays recording of the Cochran Brothers / (16:05) Meeting and working with Eddie Cochran and forming the Cochran Brothers / (17:54) Backing up Lefty Frizzell and first hearing about Elvis Presley and performing rockabilly music / (21:15) Deciding to leave rockabilly and going to country music / (22:22) Origins of Pamper Music Publishing and the first recording of the song Crazy Arms / (24:24) Getting Crazy Arms to Ray Price /

(24:40) Harlan Howard sending Pamper Music the song Heartaches By The Number / (26:10) Arriving in Nashville in January of 1960 during a snow storm and staying at Mom Upchurch's boarding house / (27:50) Being introduces to Tootsie Bess and being taken to Tootsie's Orchard Lounge / (28:50) Building the songwriting garage/house with Willie Nelson and songs written there / (30:35) Introduction of Hank Cochran's wife / (31:00) Suzy Cochran knowing that the song Ocean Front Property was going to be a hit / (32:35) Finding and signing Willie Nelson to Pamper Music / (34:10) Taking the new tires of Roger Miller's car before it was repossessed / (35:20) Getting money from Hal Smith to pay off his personal debts / (36:10) Memories of hanging a Tootsies Orchard Lounge and how he got his facial scar / (39:20) Writing the song I Fall To Pieces with Harlan Howard and singing it to Owen Bradley / (41:20) Patsy Cline hearing the song /
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Cochran, Hank; Country Music Hall of Fame & Museum (Nashville, Tenn.);
